title: may bank holiday 2020
story: This will be the second time the date has been moved in history. But why is it being shted Normally the Early May bank holiday falls on the first Monday of May.But next year it wont be on May , it will be on Friday .The government announced the change of date in June to mark the th anniversary of VE Day.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day which took place on Tuesday, May , .It was the day on which allied forces announced the surrender of Germany in Europe.It marked the end of Adolf Hitler’s war and sparked celebrations around the world.The day before at .pm on May , , Germany had surrendered.Hitler had committed suicide a week earlier leaving Grand Admiral Donitz of the German army to admit defeat.The Normandy landings in June  had proved instrumental in achieving victory for the allies, as had the huge eastern offensives of the USSR.Six years of war that had cost the lives of millions had finally come to a close.

title: highs lows politics 2019 brexit
story: But amid all the chaos and conniving,  had its comic moments in the ­corridors of power. Sunday Political Editor David Wooding hands out his annual gongs – The Wooders.Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson deluded herself she would be the next PM and toured the land in a coach bearing her giant mugshot on the side.But she didn’t even manage to win her own seat back.At least it cheered up the second most annoying party leader, the SNP’s Nicola Sturgeon, who punched the air in glee at claiming her Scots rival’s scalp.You wait two years for a Labour star to jump ship — then he does it twice in a few weeks.Following his aborted leadership bid, Chuka Umunna launched a new party, Change UK.But he became so fond of change, he did it again and joined the Lib Dems.Now he’s coping with more change after voters booted him out.Expelled left-winger Derek Hatton is readmitted into the Labour Party after a -year wait — only to be kicked out again  hours later.Comeback king Nigel Farage launched the Brexit Party.But within hours, pranksters registered its email address as a porn site.He was swamped with offers from East European women offering a “stress-free” massage.Bet he needed a rub down after his party bombed in the election.John Bercow stood down as Commons Speaker after ten years and was then accused of demanding £million to appear on TV’s I’m A Celebrity.He denied the claims but Brexit-backing MPs would happily have paid Remainer Bercow handsomely to get him out of the Westminster jungle.Naughty-but-nice Trade Secretary Liz Truss attended The Big Sausage event in Norfolk, saying it was, “ticking rather a lot of my boxes”.Asked to try a Gloucester Old Spot banger, she enthused: “That’s one of the best offers I’ve had all year.”It perhaps explains why Liz enjoyed working in a well-hung Parliament so much.Housing minister James Brokenshire showed off his new kitchen which boasts FOUR matching ovens.The revelation must have left the PM wondering where to put his “oven-ready” Brexit deal.It prompted one stunned MP to ask: “Is he running a pizza business on the side ”A miserable year for Jeremy Corbyn as his party and football team tanked.After his election defeat, the Labour leader assured fellow Arsenal fans he wouldn’t be applying for the vacant job of Gunners team boss.Just as well, as he’d probably borrow £billion to buy more left wingers and strikers but remain neutral on whether to play in Europe.Commons leader Jacob Rees-Mogg was dubbed “insolent” and “insufferable” when he reclined almost horizontally on the Commons’ green benches during a late-night Brexit debate.He refused to budge, amid cries of, “Sit up, man!”But the posh wind-up merchant smiled and nodded when one angry MP sarcastically suggested he should be supplied with a pillow.Spoon-bending psychic Uri Geller vowed to use his “telepathic powers” to stop Jeremy Corbyn becoming PM.After the election, he claimed he influenced Boris Johnson’s landslide victory by giving him a spoon energised with “mind positivity”.Chris “Failing” Grayling quit as Transport Secretary after a string of Brexit planning blunders — including awarding a cross-Channel ferry contract to a firm with no ships.Labour Deputy Leader Tom Watson shed st in two years by giving up sugar and taking up exercise.He became so thin that Corbynista “assassins” missed their target in a plot to oust him.Slimline Watson then decided to cast off his ­political baggage and quit as an MP.Shadow Education Secretary Angela ­Rayner has been showered with compliments about her figure after going on a “half-portions” diet.She quipped: “Fat birds don’t win elections.”Neither do slim turkeys when Corbyn is leader.Boris Johnson almost botched his leadership bid after a “screaming row” with his girlfriend over a wine stain on her sofa.Police were called by neighbours who reported “a lot of smashing” from the home he shared with Carrie Symonds.What happened next remains secret.Perhaps it was a ­cover-up — by an upholstery firm.Cops ordered a McDonald’s outlet to stop selling milkshakes during a rally by Nigel Farage in Edinburgh — in case they were used as missiles by customers.The Brexit Party boss completed the visit unscathed, only to be “milkshaked” in Newcastle.Loveable No pup Dilyn outshines ­Cameron, May, Johnson and even Larry the Downing Street cat.The seven-month-old Jack Russell-cross from an animal rescue charity moved in with BoJo’s girlfriend Carrie and always steals the show at official receptions.A real yappy ending.Hapless Karen Bradley admitted she didn’t believe a word she said as Northern Ireland Secretary.She dropped a clanger by saying that killings by the military and police during The Troubles were not crimes — then rowed back, insisting: “I want to be very clear. I do not believe what I said. That is not my view.”Boris Johnson brandished a kipper at his leadership hustings.But his claim that he couldn’t have it delivered by post because of EU rules proved very fishy.Channel  replaced no-shows Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage with melting ice sculptures during a debate on climate change.Viewers probably judged their performance to be less drippy than Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson’s.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson was sacked after an inquiry into who leaked details of a National Security Council meeting over plans to allow Chinese telecoms giant Huawei to help build Britain’s G network.Downing Street said the PM had, “lost confidence in his ability to serve”, but he soon ed to Cabinet.All sounds a bit, er, phoney.Boris likened himself to The Incredible Hulk as he vowed to break free from EU shackles.But when he showed schoolkids an image of the superhero during a school visit, a boy pointed at the huge muscles and said: “You’ve got boobies.”She failed to secure a Brexit deal and lost the Tories’ majority.Yet Theresa May soldiered on with everyone against her.When toppled, she didn’t quit Parliament in a huff or carp endlessly from the backbenches but showed more loyalty to her successor than he gave to her.Mrs May could prove to be the finest ex-PM Britain ever had.Remainer lawyer Gina Miller blew thousands trying to stop Brexit — but unwittingly helped deliver it.Her court victory gave Brexit-blocker MPs the right to vote down Theresa May’s “soft” departure deal.But it set off a chain of events that put Bojo in No with a majority big enough to force through a much cleaner Brexit. Thanks, Gina.They spent the past three and a half years plotting to stop Brexit at every turn.But at the General Election, voters sent them a clear message: Leave Parliament.So good riddance to Dominic Grieve, Anna Soubry, David Gauke, Laura Pidcock, Chuka Umunna, Jo Swinson, Philip Lee, Antoinette Sandbach and Sam Gyimah. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: matt ridley we are saving planet
story: Global inequality has been plunging as Africa and Asia experience faster economic growth than Europe and North America. Child mortality is at record low levels. Famine virtually went extinct. Malaria, polio and heart disease are declining.Ever since I wrote The Rational Optimist, in , I’ve been faced with, “what about. . . ” questions: What about the great recession, the euro crisis, Syria, Ukraine, Donald Trump  How can I possibly say that things are getting better, given all that The answer is: Because bad things happen while the world still gets better.That is to say, our population and economy would grow, but we would learn how to reduce what we take from the planet. And so it has proved.Scientist Andrew McAfee documented this in his book More From Less, showing how some nations are beginning to use less metal, less water and less land.This does not quite fit with what the Extinction Rebellion lot are telling us.But the next time you hear Sir David Attenborough say: “Anyone who thinks you can have infinite growth on a planet with finite resources is either a madman or an economist,” ask him this: “But whateconomic growth means using less stuff, not more ”For example, a drink can contains  grams of aluminium, much of it recycled. In  it contained  grams.Substituting the former for the latter is a contribution to economic growth, but it reduces the resources consumed per drink.As for Britain, our consumption of “stuff” probably peaked around the turn of the century. The evidence is there.In  Chris Goodall, an investor in electric vehicles, published research showing the UK was now using not just relatively less stuff every year, but absolutely less.Events have since vindicated his thesis. The quantity of all resources consumed per person in Britain fell by a third between  and , from . tonnes to . tonnes.That’s a faster decline than the increase in the number of people, so it means fewer resources consumed overall.Think about your own home. Mobile phones have the computing power of room-sized computers of the s. I use mine instead of a camera, radio, torch, compass, map, calendar, watch, CD player newspaper and a pack of cards.LED light bulbs consume about a quarter as much electricity as incandescent bulbs for the same light. Modern buildings generally contain less steel and more of it is recycled. Offices use much less paper.Even in cases when the use of stuff is not falling, it is rising more slowly than expected.For instance, how much water the world consumed in  was half as much as experts in the s predicted. Inventiveness allowed more efficient irrigation for agriculture, the biggest user of water.Until recently, most economists assumed these improvements were almost always in vain, becauseyou cut the cost of something, people would just use more of it. Make lights less energy hungry and people leave them on for longer.But Andrew McAfee argues that doesn’t hold up. Suppose you switch from incandescent to LED bulbs in your house and save about three-quarters of your electricity bill for lighting. You might leave more lights on for longer, but surely not four times as long.Efficiencies in agriculture mean the world is now approaching “peak farmland”. Despite the growing number of people and their demand for more and better food, the productivity of agriculture is rising so fast that human needs can be supplied by a shrinking amount of land.In , Jesse Ausubel, of The Rockefeller University in New York, and his colleagues argued that thanks to modern technology, we use  per cent less land to produce a given quantity of food compared with  years ago.By  it is estimated that an area the size of India will have been released from the plough and the cow.Perhaps the most surprising statistic is that Britain is using steadily less energy.John Constable, of the Global Warming Policy Forum think tank, points out that although the UK’s economy has almost trebled since , and our population is up by  per cent, energy consumption has fallen by almost ten per cent.This is not necessarily good news, Constable argues. Although the improving energy efficiency of light bulbs, planes and cars is part of the story, it also means we are importing more embedded energy in products, having driven much of our steel, aluminium and chemical industries abroad with some of the world’s highest energy prices.In fact, all this energy-saving might cause problems.Innovation requires experiments . Experiments require energy. So cheap energy is crucial.Thus, energy may be the one resource that a prospering population should be using more of.Since its inception, the environmental movement has been obsessed by finite resources. The two books that kicked off the green industry in the early s, The Limits To Growth, in America, and BlueprintFor Survival, in Britain, both lamented the imminent exhaustion of metals, minerals and fuels.The Limits To Growth predicted thatgrowth continued, the world would run out of gold, mercury, silver, tin, zinc, copper and lead well before . School textbooks soon echoed these claims.This caused the economist Julian Simon to challenge the ecologist Paul Ehrlich to a bet that five metalswould cost less in  than in .The Stone Age did not end for lack of stone, Simon said, arguing that we would find substitutesmetals grew scarce.Simon won the bet easily, and Ehrlich sniped that: “The one thing we’ll never run out of is imbeciles.”To this day, none of those metals has signicantly risen in price nor run out. A modern irony is that many green policies advocated now would actually reverse the trend towards using less stuff.A wind farm requires far more concrete and steel than a system based on gas. Environmental opposition to nuclear power has hindered the generating system that needs the least land, least fuel and least steel or concrete per megawatt.Burning wood instead of coal in power stations means the exploitation of more land — and even higher emissions. Organic farming uses more land than conventional methods.Technology has put us on a path to a cleaner, greener planet. We don’t need to veer in a new direction. To do so risks retarding progress.As we enter the third decade of this century, I’ll make a prediction.By the end of it we will see less poverty, less child mortality, less land devoted to agriculture.There will be more tigers, whales, forests and nature reserves. Britons will be richer and each of us will use fewer resources.The global political future may be uncertain, but the environmental and technological trends are pretty clear — and pointing in the right direction. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tony blair labour pension vanish
story: Army veterans, teachers, police, paramedics and firefighters are victims of a scam that went undetected for a decade.They had trustingly transferred savings into rogue schemes which were enrolled with HMRC and the Pensions Regulator, giving them an air of legitimacy. Employers such as the MoD and the NHS had said they were safe.But it simply wasn’t true . . . and at least  rogue operators were free to roam in a “scammer’s paradise”.To add insult to injury, the victims — some of whom have reported feeling suicidal — are now being fined for unknowingly participating in these schemes, which broke tax laws.And who’s to blame  Tony Blair and his Labour government, who relaxed rules around HMRC enrolment in , allowing dodgy pension schemes to sign up with virtually no checks.This was supposed to bring “security, dignity and comfort in old age”. Instead it has unleashed a nightmare.Perhaps instead of lecturing us on Brexit, Blair should reflect on his devastating legacy.IN her bid to become the next Labour leader, Rebecca Long-Bailey has promised “progressive patriotism”.It sounds as nonsensical as the party’s economic policies. After all, there’s nothing “progressive” about this vile, anti-semitic version of the party.Nor is there anything “patriotic” about Long-Bailey’s loyalty to Jeremy Corbyn, the man who counts Hamas, Hezbollah and the IRA as his friends.So it comes as no surprise that Corbyn’s cronies are apparently trying to shorten the Labour leadership contest in order to boost Long-Bailey’s chances and “stitch-up” other hopefuls.Her proclamation of patriotism shows utter desperation.Labour spent years treating anyone who’s proud to be British as lowle scum, only to have that backfire on them at the election.Many are proud of this country and enthusiastic about Brexit.It’s a bit too late for Corbynistas to pretend they feel the same.IT looks set to be a very happy New Year for many British workers.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced that the minimum wage for over s will rise by p to £. an hour in April.After years of “Spreadsheet Phil” Hammond and his Brexit fearmongering, this is exactly the boost Britain needs — both for the economy and spirit.So let’s join the three million who’ll be toasting Mr Javid on New Year’s Eve. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new decade improve politics
story: But let’s be frank. Things can only improve on the last four years of anger, ision and political paralysis.A period which should have been pivotal to our country saw it barely governed at all. That all changed at pm on December .Boris Johnson’s thumping election win gives us the greatest opportunity for radical renewal since at least .That means finally achieving Brexit  days from now and then, we hope, rapidly ­striking trade deals with Brussels and the world’s greatest economies.It means a dramatic, imaginative ­Budget to turbo-charge both those “left-behind” regions which voted Tory for the first time and the wider economy.We share too the  vision of our readers: For huge NHS investment to continue and a long-term social care solution be put in place.That tax breaks and rate cuts must renew our dilapidated High Streets and help small firms thrive and create jobs.That rough sleeping must be slashed, even ended. That wages must be driven up and food banks rendered redundant.That the Tories must continue striving for a cleaner environment without ­caving in to economy-wrecking panic.And we of course share the desire for a kinder, more united country — echoed by the open letter from faith, ­culture, sport and business leaders.The Sun is optimistic about that too.In fact we do not agree we have suffered a “decade of ision”. Yes, it was tough financially. But we were far from ided at, say, the  Olympics.The anger in our Parliament, offices, factories and homes was caused by Brexit, specically by some Remainers’ refusal to accept defeat, and by a Labour Party engulfed by the hostile hard-left.The Brexit heat is fast dissipating now. Boris’s triumph saw to that. Many Remainers are making their peace with it . . . and even seeing its opportunities.Which leaves but one obstacle to the national healing.No one has done more to ide us than Jeremy Corbyn, his thuggish, often anti-Semitic followers and his obnoxious media apologists.Their relentless hatred and dishonest demonisation of opponents toxied both political discourse and Labour’s election fortunes.Yet none of the contenders to replace Corbyn grasps this reality: They can remain a Twitter-obsessed, Tory-hating clique of middle-class Marxist posers calling each other “comrade” but disconnected from working people.Or be viable, mainstream contenders for Government. But not both.Will they make the right choice  It’s January , , and we live in hope.We are far more sure that Britain, fully independent for the first time in  years, will enjoy a golden decade in the ’s.Happy New Year to you all! Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg shift opinions
story: Thanks to the -year-old Swedish climate change campaigner many more of us are eco-warriors these days. Whichever box we ticked in the election, millions of us vote green with our lestyles.A recent survey of Sun readers showed  per cent recognise climate change is real and that  per cent of us worry more about our environmental impact now than they did five years ago.And  per cent of Sun readers want to make their habits greener still.Some of them make their voices heard.Retired receptionist Eileen Webster, , says “climate change is the big issue facing the next generation”, while Anna Lubecka, , demands new PM Boris Johnson, “start making good plans for climate change”.Attitudes to environmentalism have shted so much that being green is now no longer the preserve of lentil-munching hippies and Swampy, it is totally mainstream.No trendy bar would now dare put plastic straws in their cocktails.We’ve all got used to carrying Love Island-style water bottles and happily adopted reusable coffee cups. This year they pulled off a plastic-free Glastonbury, despite a few hiccups.We’ve long stopped grumbling about taking our own bags to the supermarket and got used to stuffing our pockets with them when we leave the house.So now in England, the average person uses less than a tenth of the number of single-use plastic bags than we did five years ago. Only around ten a year, compared to  in .As electric cars have improved, we’ve all been seduced — and not just by Tesla’s new “bulletproof” Cybertruck. Overall, demand for electric cars has jumped, with the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders finding that this November alone electric car sales leaped by . per cent, with more than three times as many new battery-electric vehicles registered as in the same month in .Nowhere  is it clearer that green has become the new black than in fashion, where criticism of fast fashion has led to trends for vintage, second hand and renting rather than buying.On the high street, companies such as HM have launched their “conscious collection” , fashion bible Vogue has championed sustainable designs, while French President Emmanuel Macron’s “fashion pact” — presented at the G summit and intended to make the industry more sustainable — has been signed by more than  brands, including Nike, Zara and Gap.All these changes prove how far we have come and the impact Greta has had.Hearing her, strong and calm, on Radio ’s Today programme this week, what struck me is that now another change is needed.This time a sht not in our actions, but in how we approach the environmental debate.It’s not beliefs but attitudes that need to change. Until now, environmental issues have been too isive.Butwe want real change we’ve got to move beyond blame.It puts people off environmental issues when campaigners hector and shame them.When wealthy celebrities such as Sir David Attenborough criticise normal people for taking holidays with cheap flights, or actress Emma Thompson jets back from America to harass normal people driving to work.In the same way Extinction Rebellion threatens to lose potential supporters when it starts fights with commuters trying to board their morning train or cause mayhem in central London.The real danger is that by being so aggressive, these green campaigners risk putting people off.Greta seems to know this. She is much calmer than she used to be when speaking in public.Rather than getting angry or emotional, instead she has stressed the importance of just, “listening to the scientists”.As usual, we could learn from her.The reality is most people want to be green.We are all concerned about global warming, pollution in the seas and the kind of planet we are creating for our grandkids. But you can’t shame people into doing something.Diesel drivers — especially White Van Man — shouldn’t be harassed just for getting to work. I’m sure they would buy more environmentally friendly vehiclesthey could afford to.Likewise, no one should be shamed for taking a flight — who knows what other measures they might be taking, such as living in a carbon neutral home What the planet needs least is more fighting. Instead we need grown-up debate.The answer to the climate crisis isn’t to criticise each other — it’s to work together to make real change. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hugs clean air holidays gadgets trends 2020
story: The -year-old predicted the clean eating craze, the rise of the snowflake generation and metrosexual men and she was one of the first to warn of the  financial crash.Today we hear what New Yorker Marian – whose Annual Trends report is a bible for companies wanting to know the next big thing – is predicting for , which she believes will be the Year of the Hug.It has never been easier to reach out to friends and colleagues anywhere in the world.But the more digitally connected we all become, the more we risk becoming disconnected emotionally and physically.We each live in our own inidualised, personally curated bubble — and we are feeling the impact.At our core, humans are social animals. We need contact — and not just emotional — but physical.There’s even a psychological term for it, skin hunger.People are responding to this tech-driven disconnect by seeking out physical contact in any way they can.The most obvious example is the rise of hugging.There’s a lot more hugging as a greeting between men than there used to be, even between sporting opponents.And what on earth happened to the stand-offish Brits  Great British Bake Off contestants spend nearly as much time holding hands and wrapping their arms around each other as they do baking.We have become so hungry for touch that we don’t even need a human partner.The odds are that someone you know will have received a weighted blanket for Christmas.It is essentially a duvet cover filled with plastic or glass pellets or beads.Manufacturers say the even pressure they exert on your body promotes the release of well-being chemical serotonin and sleep hormone melatonin, while reducing stress-related hormone cortisol.In plain language we’re talking about feeling the comfort and security of being cradled, evenit’s by a blanket rather than in the arms of a loved one.For those who want to take the experience of being hugged to a whole new level, Otonamaki, the Japanese practice of adult swaddling, will become popular in .After getting into a foetal position, the client is bound tightly in sheets, then gently rocked for  minutes.I ran across a tweet not long ago that read: “My phone just said, ‘Welcome home’, and I instinctively replied, ‘I love you’. Then I realised I meant it.”We may be interacting with our fellow humans less often, but we’re more than making up for it with digital interactions, even to the point of developing feelings for these devices.As our devices get smarter and master the intricacies of natural language processing, we will increasingly see them as confidants, friends and even romantic partners.Already people are interacting with chatbots instead of flesh-and-blood therapists.And we’re seeing all sorts of digital apps promising to improve our mental health, from Moodfit and MoodMission to Happy.As developers figure out how to make our smart devices ever more personable, it doesn’t take a soothsayer to recognise that a global population increasingly suffering from loneliness and disconnectedness will find solutions of a sort in these gadgets.The desire for clean air in cities will not only lead to pricier houses on less polluted streets but tourists will give up city breaks for holidays in the country, where the air is good.As living in places with clean air becomes a luxury with a high price tag, expect new takes on face masks to become a must-have item for people in cities and a race towards rural living.Expect an explosion of products, from vegan leather to plant-based burgers and articial wood.If you buy a vegan burger and cook it at home, you have consumed a burger made with eight times less water and CO than a conventional beef burger.These sorts of products may be described as “fake” but the feelings people get of having made an ethically better choice are very real.Uncertainty begets fear, so look out for a rise in preppers — survivalists preparing for Armageddon.In the US, prepping is mainstream enough for Costco to sell a £, one-year stockpile of survival food for four.Survivalists are at the extreme end of the bunker trend.More mainstream are the millions who aren’t worried enough to go all-out prepper but still view the outside world as a threat.Driven by concerns about personal security and terrorism, CCTV covering public and commercial spaces is becoming a global norm.London is sixth in the world for TV surveillance, the only non-Chinese city in the top eight.And sales of home video surveillance on smartphones, courtesy of Google Nest, Ring and Wyze Cam, are booming.The global market is expected to rise from £billion to £billion by .Expect the self-tracking trend to run and run.For more and more people, there’s something irresistible about gadgets that put statistics to common everyday activities.For things that can’t yet be tracked automatically, they can input data manually — MyMoodTracker for emotions, MyNetDiary for nutrition and PoopLog for toilet visits.Google announced it intended to buy Fitbit for nearly £billion, prompting some to say they will ditch their device out of concern that Google will sell their health data to insurance companies.But rather than wait to buy third-party data, insurance companies are already getting into the game.: Single, professional women will become the new free-spending yuppies.: Publishes a study of the soft modern male, who she described as “metrosexual man”.: Predicts “sleep is the new sex” and “clean eating”. Forecasts the sub-prime crisis that led to the  financial crash.: Identies a new “snowflake” mindset where “everybody wants to save the Earth but no one wants to help Mum with the dishes”.: Identies Daddy bloggers as more fathers bring up kids.: Forecasts the rise of “truthiness” – where facts seem to matter little.: Predicts rise of gender-neutral society. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cats seized micro chipped plans
story: The Government is consulting on making it compulsory for all Brits to get their felines chipped.It is already illegal for dog owners to not microchip their pets, and those who flout the law can be prosecuted and handed £ fines.One proposal being considered is handing councils the power to seize the cats and get them microchipped.The pets would then be given back to their owners who would be billed for the ID tag, typically around £.But the owner could face a finethey refused to pay the bill.The consultation on the proposed shake-up closes on January .Zac Goldsmith, Animal Welfare Minister, said: “Microchips are often the only hope of reuniting lost pets with their owners so it truly is the best New Year’s resolution you could make to protect your furry friend in .“I urge cat owners to microchip their cat and for dog-owners to make sure the details on the chip are up to date.”Jacqui Cuff, from the charity Cats Protection, said: “It is so important that cat owners microchip their pet cats as it is a safe and permanent form of identication.“Cats love to explore, and are also great escape artists, so microchipping is important for cats, even those that live indoors.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announced six weeks ago that infants abandoned by their ISIS fighter parents would be brought back to the UK.The Sun can reveal that government lawyers privately flagged up the risk that the move could trigger a slew of fresh claims under human rights laws.The jihadis could exploit their children’s mercy lts out of the war zone by claiming their right to family reunion to successfully overturn any ban on their .But the decision was taken by Mr Raab despite the legal warnings as well as fierce opposition from the Home Secretary, The Sun has also learned.Priti Patel argued against the rescues because of the danger their parents could cause - and was backed by Chancellor Sajid Javid and Defence Secretary Ben Wallace - but she was overruled.In addition, The Sun can also reveal that the Foreign Office and Crown Prosecution Service is looking afresh at bringing back as many as  captured British jihadis to stand trial.It is estimated that prosecutions could be brought against up to a third of the roughly  fighters locked up in camps in Kurdistan, who were taken prisoner when Islamic State was defeated.A fresh review of their status has been launched under heavy pressure from the US, who want the UK government to start taking action over the detainees now that the election is over.So far, only three children have been brought back, but as many as  more could follow.Announcing the mission in November, Mr Raab said only orphans and unaccompanied minors would be brought back to Britain as he dubbed it “the right thing to do”.He added: “These innocent children should never have been subjected to the horrors of war”.Responding to the revelations, Commons Foreign Affairs committee chairman Tom Tugendhat repeated his call for legal reforms as the current law is not up to scratch.Mr Tugendhat said: “They are British, they were radicalised here, they are our problem, but we must look very hard at bringing in legislation to toughen up the law first.“Courts must be able to convict people who have betrayed the country and then lock them up for a long time. assassinating General Soleimani - THE most effective force fighting Daesh , Al Nusrah, Al Qaeda et al—is extremely dangerous  a foolish escalation.The US bears responsibility for all consequences of its rogue adventurism.Soleimani, , was commander of the Quds Force, the elite unit of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards, which the Trump administration designated as a terror organisation in April last year.US secretary of state Mike Pompeo posted a video he said showed Iraqis dancing in the street thankful that General Soleimani is no more.Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi condemned the assassination of Gen Soleimani and said the air strike was an act of aggression that that would lead to war in Iraq, the region and the world.He said the men killed were major symbols in achieving victory against ISIS terrorists.Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, long supported by Iran, condemned what it called criminal US aggression.Dalia Dassa Kaye, an Iran expert at Rand Corporation, a US think-tank, tweeted: The notion that President Trump doesnt want war with Iran rings hollowthis was a deliberate attack.Killing this target will likely be viewed as an act of war regardless.Former Middle East minister Alistair Burt said the airstrike could cause a huge potential escalation of the conflict, of which the consequences are unknown.Soleimanis killing follows the New Years Eve attack by Iran-backed militias on the US Embassy in Baghdad.The two-day embassy attack, which ended on Wednesday, prompted Mr Trump to order about  US troops deployed to the Middle East.That siege followed US air strikes on the militia in Iraq and Syria.On Thursday, US Defense Secretary Mark Esper warned the US military would pre-emptively strike Iranian-backed forces in Iraq and Syriathere were signs the paramilitary groups were planning more attacks against American bases and personnel in the region.A senior Iraqi politician and high-level security official, speaking to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said al-Muhandis had arrived to the airport in a convoy to receive Gen Soleimani, whose plane had arrived from either Lebanon or Syria.The American drone strike saw multiple missiles hit two cars carrying Gen Soleimani and several officials with Iranian-backed militias as they were leaving the airport.Qasem Soleimani became head of the Quds Force in , a position in which he kept a low profile for years while he strengthened Irans ties with Hezbollah in Lebanon, Syrias government and Shiite militia groups in Iraq.He was known as The Shadow Commander by his enemies, spending most of his career as a recluse and a spook.The Quds Force, tasked with carrying out operations beyond Irans borders, shored up support for Syrias Assad when he looked close to defeat in the civil war raging since  and also helped defeat ISIS in Iraq.Former CIA officer John Maguire said Soleimani was the single most powerful operative in the Middle East.Soleimani had survived several assassination attempts against him by Western, Israeli and Arab agencies over the past two decades.The Trump administration designed Soleimanis Quds Force as a terror organisation in April last year.He was the second most powerful person in Iran behind the Ayatollah Ali Khamenei at the time of his assassination.He was hailed as a national hero by many in Iran and was awarded the Order of Zolfiqar medal, Irans highest military honour, last year.Iraqi state television said that five Iraqis and two guests had been killed. Pictures showed burning debris on an airport road.A senior Iraqi politician told AP that Soleimanis body was identied by the ring he wore.The strike was carried out by the Joint Special Operation Command.The White House said the attack was carried out at the direction of the president.Mr Trump ordered the strike at a time when the US Congress was in recess.Responding to the drone strike, Democrats took aim at Trumps decision.Former Vice President Joe Biden said in a statement: Trump just tossed a stick of dynamite into a tinderbox, and he owes the American people an explanation of the strategy...much remains unknown, but Iran will surely respond. We could be on the brink of a major conflict across the Middle East.Presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren wrote on Twitter: Soleimani was a murderer, responsible for the deaths of thousands, including hundreds of Americans. But this reckless move escalates the situation with Iran and increases the likelihood of more deaths and new Middle East conflict. Our priority must be to avoid another costly war.House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the administration conducted the airstrike without consultation of Congress or an authorisation for use of military force against Iran.She said it risked provoking a dangerous escalation in violence.Bernie Sanders pointed to the approximately , American lives that have already been lost in the Middle East.He said in a statement: Trumps dangerous escalation brings us closer to another disastrous war in the Middle East that could cost countless lives and trillions more dollars.Trump promised to end endless wars, but this action puts us on the path to another one.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new parliament must recapture spirit
story: NewsopinionNew parliament must recapture spirit of  and commit to protect refugeesRos Wynne-Jones writes that next week, MPs willto vote on the amended bill, which sets out the terms of the transition period as the country prepares to leave the EUShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionChild refugees queue to receive food " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs the new year and a new ­political era begins, and as we look for clues to how Boris Johnson ’s reign will play out, there can be few signals as blatant. As almost the first act of the new Tory Government, flexing the muscles of its new -seat majority, protections for child refugees built into the EU Withdrawal Agreement Bill were dropped, along with protections for British workers. Since , the rights of child ­refugees to join relatives in another EU country have been protected by a bill that said these rights would continue after Brexit . But four days before Christmas, the Government amended Clause  of the EU Withdrawal Bill. Now ­ministers will just have to give “a statement to Parliament”. Next week, MPs willto vote on the amended bill, which sets out the terms of the transition period as we prepare to leave the EU. When they do, they should listen to the words of Lord Alf Dubs, the Labour peer who came to Britain aged six in , who was among , children saved from the Nazis by the Kindertransport evacuations. “To all those MPs who will vote this week, I want to want to say that Britain has an honourable humanitarian tradition when it comes to child ­refugees,” former MP Lord Dubs, now , says. “It is a shocking, shocking thing to deny them safety. I would urge you to speak out and say as a country, we are better than this.” As millions of us spent New Year’s Day eating Quality Street and watching the Von Trapps escape the Nazis over the Austrian mountains, there will have been children taking that same desperate route through the ­mountains of Europe. “This was a bombshell,” Lord Dubs says. “It wasn’t in the manesto. There is no electoral mandate for it.” In , Lord Dubs’ campaigning led to legislation known as the Dubs Amendment, which hoped to get safe passage for unaccompanied child refugees during the migrant crisis.  “Back then, there were Tory MPs and even some government ministers who would tell me to keep going, but the mood and composition of the Government has changed,” he says. “This tells me we had better be careful about where government goes next.” Alf Dubs was six when the Nazis took over his home city of Prague. “I have bits of memory,” he says. “I remember at school we had to tear out the picture of the Czech President Benes and paste in a picture of Adolf Hitler. There were German soldiers everywhere. “My father was Jewish and so he left first. His cousins decided to stay and in  they were sent to Auschwitz. I remember being at the station in Prague waiting for the Kindertransport, German soldiers everywhere, but I was too young to feel real danger.” The train was one of eight from Prague to London organised by British hero Nicholas Winton, whom the Mirror awarded a Pride of Britain letime achievement award to in . Winton’s trains saved  children from the Nazi death camps.  “It was such a long train journey, two days, and then we reached the Dutch border and the older children cheered because they knew we were safe,” Lord Dubs says. “We went by boat from the Hook of Holland to Harwich and then to Liverpool Street. I was lucky – my father had got to the UK. “My mother was trying to leave but she couldn’t get an exit permit. At Gestapo headquarters, officials threw her down the stairs. She landed in a heap but they threw her passport after her. She was able to escape, and arrived in London the day before Germany invaded Poland.” Soon after, his father died of a heart attack, and his mother was ­scrubbing floors in a Manchester restaurant. Their son was made a Lord in .  After a letime of campaigning for the rights of other refugee children, Lord Dubs recently visited the camps of northern France and the Greek islands. “The conditions are shocking in Greece,” he says. “And it is worse in Calais now than in the time of the Jungle, because the police are taking their tents and sleeping bags. Families are just living under tarpaulins. ­ Children are vulnerable and in danger. “If you take away people’s legal path to safety, they are more likely to look at other dangerous ways of getting across the Channel – whether that’s on the back of a lorry or an unsafe dinghy.”

In a typically concise , word blog post, which frankly weaposre not totally sure isnapost a joke, the Prime Ministeraposs most senior advisor sets out the qualities heaposs seeking in people to help him run the country. Mr Cummings, who is paid just shy of £, a year, admitted the fresh push to hire weirdos is down to Number  lacking expertise, and his having to make decisions heaposs in no way qualied to tackle. story: NewsCouples £, Persimmon dream home plagued by regular raw sewage floodingDaniel and Katy Patrick, from Redditch, Worcestershire, said their drains back up into their washing machine so they have been cleaning their familys clothes in the contaminated waterShareCommentsByLorraine King:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsDaniel Patrick outside his Persimmon home in Redditch, Worcestershire " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA coupleaposs dream £, family home has turned into a nightmare amid claims their four-bedroom house regularly floods with raw sewage. Daniel Patrick,  and his partner Katy, , say the back garden is a no-go area at the property they bought off-plan from Persimmon homes in Redditch, Worcestershire, in August . The couple, who have two children, say they were so excited to get into the house that they didnapost notice any faults at their home at first. However it wasnapost long before their downstairs loo began flooding with raw sewage any time they flushed the toilet downstairs. The couple say the back garden also floods with rain water - and that the builders confessed there was no external drainage system fitted to their home. On top of that, they also claim they later discovered that the drains had been backing up into their washing machine so they had been cleaning the familyaposs clothes in raw sewage water. After three neighbours complained of the same problem, Daniel now says that pipework has been completed - but just causes waste from three other homes to gather in their garden. Daniel, an IT manager, said: Since moving in we have had raw sewage in our property twice. Within a few days of moving in I approached the site staff with my concerns regarding the rear garden, my concerns were ignored and I was told it was due to the drains having to be completed.  The first time was last year Christmas none of our toilets would flush and waste was coming up into the downstairs toilet and into the room itself. The second time, around February, Persimmon acknowledged there was an issue and someone was sent out, both times tools were found in the drains that we left over from the build. The dog walked it through the house and I tried to claim for cleaning and replacing carpets and they said no- in the end we have had to replace all the downstairs with laminate flooring in case it happens again. On top of everything the pair say they were told by plumbers sent by Persimmon that water waste was due to a faulty washing machine- Daniel and Katie quickly replaced it but the problem happened again. As the Christmas break comes to an end, families willto the regular routine of school runs and nursery drop-offs. And a survey of , mums and dads has revealed almost one thirdend up being late for work at least once a week because they’re getting their little ones ready. The research found it typically takes  minutes to prepare a child for a journey - carrying out tasks such as getting their shoes and coat on. Over the course of a year this amounts to a staggering  HOURS, or four whole days.  More than a quarter of parents admit they bribe their kids to speed the process up, with sweets and the promise of their favourite music being played topping the list of incentives. Toddlers aged between two and three are the worst culprits when it comes to getting into the car quickly and easily, according to SEAT UK, with  per cent agreeing that the ‘terrible twos’ are the most dficult to marshal. The job of getting children out of the house and into the car adds, on average,  minutes to the routine while one in  families reported it takes up to  minutes longer to start their morning journey since having kids. Rob Fryer, head of product at SEAT UK, said: “It won’t be a surprise to parents of young children that getting into the car and setting off on a journey, however long or short, is such a challenge. “Whether it’s last-minute toilet trips or deciding which of their toys they’d like to take in the car with them, children can make the job of leaving the house seem daunting.”  The study found London children are the most likely to make their parents late for work, with  per cent of mums and dads in the capital reporting they are late every day because of the morning routine. As a result, one in four London parents - more than anywhere  in the UK - dread the daily task of bundling their loved ones into the family vehicle. At the other end of the scale, Scottish children appear to be better behaved when it comes to leaving the house, with  per cent of parents north of the border saying their offspring never make them late. Among the most likely things to make leaving the house dficult include the task of getting children strapped into their seats in the car, last-minute toilet trips and struggling with the large amount of child-related paraphernalia which needs to be loaded into the car for each trip.  But the additional time spent is mostly taken up by children taking too long to put shoes and coats on before heading out. SEAT carried out the research to highlight its seven-seat Tarraco SUV, which has been designed with families in mind and has . The Taracco, available with a choice of two petrol and three diesel engines, is a practical family car with up ,-litres of boot space. Rob Fryer added: “At SEAT we’ve included a raft of family-friendly elements to our Tarraco that means that we can make this a little bit easier. “The hands-free boot opening makes access easy, while the seven seats can be configured quickly at the pull of a button. “And with Apple CarPlay also available, it’s easy to keep the tots amused once in the vehicle.”

title: ultimate list 20 things you
story: NewsUltimate list of  things you can do to help yourself and others in Scientists say doing a selfless act can make us feel better and can even work as a painkiller, in addition itll make you feel more fulfilled, healthier and happierShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  JAN NewsA selfless act can make us feel better " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little bit of positivity goes a long way and a good deed doesn’t just benefit the person on the receiving end. Scientists have found a selfless act can make us feel better and can even work as a painkiller. So here are  things you can do for  that won’t just help others, they’ll actually make you feel happier, healthier and more fulfilled... Knit to help premature babies Join the thousands of volunteers knitting little octopuses for babies up and down the country. They’re not toys but medical devices that stop babies from pulling on their tubes while they’re in incubators.Knitting even has its own health benefits and can lead to lower blood pressure . Get involved by visiting octopusforapreemie.Join a brass band Tooting a tuba can help to relieve stress, improve mental health and make your lungs as efficient as an athlete’s. With a bit of practice, you’ll be making sweet music others can enjoy and studies have shown music improves blood flow in ways similar to statins, lowering levels of stress-related hormones. Laughing sessions Laughter really is the best medicine – it releases endorphins which enhance our sense of wellbeing, can temporarily relieve pain andyou do it for  to  minutes a day, it can burn around  calories. Because laughter is infectious, you’ll be spreading the joy far and wide. Donate stem cells, sperm and eggs  Give someone with blood cancer a second chance at le by joining the stem cell register at anthonynolan.org. And donating your sperm or eggs to couples who can’t conceive is giving them the gt of new le. Visit hfea.gov.uk. Borrow a dog If you can’t commit to having your own dog, why not borrow one you can take for walks  You’ll be helping out a dog owner and get out in nature with your new pal. Petting a dog can lower heart rate and blood pressure. Visit borrowmydoggy. Run to help the elderly Want to get fit and help the community at the same time  Run to an older person’s home where you can team up with other runners and help with something they are struggling to do themselves, such as tending to the garden or putting heavy shopping away. Visit goodgym.org. Donate your hair  Giving yourself an image revamp will boost your mental wellbeing and confidence, and you can donate your tresses to charity. Little Princesses littleprincesses.org.uk make wigs for children with cancer or,you’re feeling brave, go for the shave in aid of Macmillan. bravetheshave.macmillan.org.uk Plant a tree A chemical released by trees and plants – phytoncide – boosts the immune system. So get involved by planting a tree with the Mirror’s MillionMirrorTrees campaign or donate to a charity that will plant trees in other countries. Feed the birds Our feathered friends rely on our help during the winter months when food is scarce. Those who live in areas where there are more birds are less likely to suffer from depression, anxiety and stress. Write someone a letter You can’t beat sending a letter or a card to a friend or relative who might need cheering up. You’ll feel great for making their day and it’ll make you put the phone to one side for a while. Bake a cake Making a cake is an excellent way of practising mindfulnessmeditation isn’t for you and it gives your loved ones a treat, too.  Hug someone When we hug, it stimulates the thymus gland, which regulates the production of white blood cells and helps to keep us healthy, and boosts the immune system. Good for the hugger and huggee. Join a choir Choirs can help combat loneliness and many also give back to the community – the Liberty Choir sings in prisons and Bee Vocal is a mental health charity choir in Manchester. Find a roomie A lovely scheme which helps young people with accommodation when rent is sky-high while giving an older person support and company is homeshare.org. They find an older householder with a room to spare and carefully match them with a younger person who will provide support. Pool your skills A great way to get to know your neighbours is getting together and pooling your skills so you can help each other out in times of need. That plumber at the end of the road could one day come in very handy and your secret painting and wallpaper-hanging skills could make you a star of the street.

title: what queen doing midnight new
story: NewsWhat Queen was doing at midnight on New Year’s Eve - and why Kate Middleton wasn’t thereThe Queen enjoys New Years Eve celebration with a select few members of the Royal Family - but theres an unwritten rule for all guestsShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAll Royal Family members are invited to the Queens New Years Eve get together " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - Royal FamilySubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Most of us welcomed the new decade with one two many glassesof prosecco and a questionable rendition of Auld Lang Syne .But for the Queen and other members of the Royal Family it’s a much quieter affair. The Monarch spends the special day in Sandringham each year as part of her Christmas break, remaining at the Norfolk estate until the beginning of February. She puts out an open invitation to all members of the Royal Family to join her for the celebrations, and it’s often those who weren’t able to be there for Christmas Day who take up the offer. This year we know that the Cambridges are skipping the party as they are reportedly celebrating with Kate’s family, and Meghan and Harry are in Canada with their son Archie. However it’s likely that Prince Philip will be at her side having been released from hospital, where he was being treated for a “pre-existing condition” a few days before Christmas. Previous reports suggest that members of the family don’t go to bed until the Queen does, which means she basically gets to decide when the festivities end.  Queen’s former private secretary William Heseltine has previously confirmed this, saying: “Nobody felt it right to go to bed before the Queen did.” On New Year’s Day the Queen goes to church with members of the family. The Queen normally attends church on New Year’s Day before spending the afternoon relaxing, often going horse riding. The Monarch will stay in Sandringham until early February, preferring to mark the anniversary of her father’s death there rather than at Buckingham Palace.

story: NewsWomans chicken pox scar becomes skin cancer  years after she got the virusLouise Thorell, , from Ashington, Northumberland, is now cancer free after having three surgeries to remove it which have left her with a scar on her faceShareCommentsByBrendan McFaddenTanita Matthews:,  JAN NewsLouise Thorell had surgery on her face in an effort to get rid of skin cancer which left her with a scar " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has told how her scar from chickenpox turned into skin cancer almost  years after she contracted the virus. Louise Thorell, , from Ashington, Northumberland, was always self conscious about the scar on her face left behind from when she battled chicken pox, aged five, but thought it was harmless. But in  the scaraposs appearance started to change, and after after having series of infections, she was referred for tests by her doctor, before being rocked by the news she had skin cancer. She is now cancer free after having three surgeries to remove it which have left her with a scar on her face. Louise explained: It felt tougher, waxier than my normal skin. Around that time, I accidentally scratched my scar and after that I had issues. It would heal, a scab would form, it would fall off and an open wound would be there until a new scab would form.  I dealt with it for a few months until I got an infection. My undereye swelled and my wound site got bigger each time it would open and heal again. I got two infections in it and an infection in my nose and above my lip too. After the first infection I noticed it had changed in appearance. It had tiny little blood vessel veins around it. Louise feared the worst after going for test because thereaposs a history of skin cancer in her family. Her grandmother Lillian, who had passed away in  from lung cancer, had suffered with a melanoma on the right side of her face. She said: My Nana had melanoma on the left side of her face, pretty much the same place - mine was on my right side. I googled skin cancers as I had a feeling my scar wound had turned sinister.  I made an appointment with my doctor and was referred very quickly to the melanoma clinic in Cramlington Northumberland, which is run by doctors and nurses from Newcastle RVI hospital. When the results came back, Louise was hit with the devastating news that she had developed Basal Cell Carcinoma , a common type of skin cancer, which can be non fataltreated early. The most common cause of BCC is from overexposure to ultraviolet light, usually found on sunbeds. Louise was stunned by the diagnosis as she claims she had never used sun bedsShe also insists she makes sure she applies sun cream to her pale skin in hot weather .In November , Louise had a procedure which left her with a visible scar on her face that required corrective surgery to improve it.  She said: I had Mohs surgery. I was awake for the surgery, just under local anaesthetic. They take some of the cancer cells away. Then itaposs tested and looked under the microscope to seethere are still cancer cells in a certain section. After the first time they took cells away, I was bandaged up and was told to go for lunch and a drink and come back in two hours to seethey got all the cancer first time. Unfortunately, they hadnapost. I had to go back in theatre and get more taken off. This happened a total of three times. Three times they had to go back on my face and take cells tumour away.. At first I wasnapost expecting the sheer size of my scar to be as big as it is. I did feel awful about how I looked. I tried to joke about it and make fun to lighten my mood. This lasted a few weeks. When I started to see it healing, my goodness, my spirits were lted. I had plastic restorative surgery the same day on my face. Now I am very, very aware of my skin. I religiously apply Biooil twice daily, I put face cream on first thing in the morning and last thing at night. I donapost scrub my face, I take extra care and time on my face now.

Ashley Jernigan has a rare genetic disorder which sees the lumps appear all over her face and body and says people often stare of avoid her. The -year-old mum of four was diagnosed with neurofibromatosis when she hit puberty and has developed thousands of tumours on every part of her body since. Ashley from Montgomery, Alabama, US, said: With this condition, you can still live le like any other normal person.  Itaposs just the bullying you have to deal with. It takes a strong person to overcome what people say. Itaposs hard, itaposs really rough, and depressing. When I go out, people stare and make rude gestures. They say aposlook at her, where did she come from and whataposs wrong with herapos. I donapost want to date because of the stares. A man wouldnapost accept me. It would take a strong man to appreciate me for who I am and look past my condition. Ashley, whose mum, Lisa, died of the condition aged just , was advised by doctors not to have children as it would make the condition worse.  But she went on ignore this advice and have four children, Darnell, , Devon, , Keonna, eight, and Kaiden, five - but said with every pregnancy the condition did worsen. Ashley wants to spread the word that the condition isnapost contagious, but said some of the lumps on her body leave her in too much pain to wear shoes. Although there is a chance her children could also have or develop the genetic illness, she doesnapost want to have them tested. She added: Kids are more curious and understanding, they think itaposs chickenpox or ant bites but I just say I was born like this. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNew details have emerged over the killing of Qassem Soleimani close to Baghdad airport in a precision airstrike. The Revolutionary Guard general, one of the most powerful men in Iran, had arrived in Iraq just minutes before his death. Soleimani was in one of two cars carrying both himself and Iraq-based Popular Mobilization Forcesmilitiamen after being picked up from Baghdad International Airport. He is reported to have flown in from Damascus in Syria, which has condemned the killing.Four precision missiles struck the cars carrying Soleimani and his entourage, according to US officials. The cars were struck on an access road near the Baghdad airport. Pictures posted on social media show the burning wreckage of two cars with other Iranian officials and pro-Iran militia members also among those killed. The missiles were fired from a drone, according to anonymous US officials quoted in US media. However Iran claims that American helicopters were involved in the aposassassinationapos. The strike also killed Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis, the deputy commander of Iran-backed militias in Iraq known as thePMF, which were responsible for the recent attack on the U.S. embassy in Baghdad, officials said.  Two officials from the PMF said Soleimaniaposs body was torn to pieces in the attack. Local militia commander Abu Muntathar al-Hussaini told Reuters: Haj Soleimani and Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis were riding in one vehicle when it was struck by two successive guided missiles launched from an American helicopter while they were on their way from the arrivals hall on the road that leads out of Baghdad Airport. He said the second vehicle was carrying bodyguards from the PMF and was hit by one rocket.The American criminals had detailed information on the convoyaposs movements,apos he said. A Pentagon spokesman said: General Soleimani was actively developing plans to attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region. General Soleimani and his Quds Force were responsible for the deaths of hundreds of American and coalition service members and the wounding of thousands more. He had orchestrated attacks on coalition bases in Iraq over the last several months - including the attack on December th - culminating in the death and wounding of additional American and Iraqi personnel.  General Soleimani also approved the attacks on the US Embassy in Baghdad that took place this week. The assassinations will be seen as a massive blow to Iran, which has been locked in a long conflict with the US that escalated sharply last week with an attack on the US embassy in Iraq by pro-Iranian militiamen.  Analysts have predicted Iran is likely to respond forcefully to the targeting of Soleimani. Hours after news broke of the airstrike the US state department warned all US citizens to leave Iraq immediately. Iran and Saudi Arabia, which both share borders with a destabilised Iraq, have been involved in a aposproxy warapos.  They each follow one of the two main branches of Islam - Iran is largely Shia Muslim, while Saudi Arabia sees itself as the leading Sunni Muslim power. The US has been trying to stymie Iranaposs influence in the Middle East for years and Soleimani has survived several assassination attempts against him by Western, Israeli and Arab agencies over the past two decades. Iranaposs President Hassan Rouhani has labelled the rocket strike a aposcowardly actapos.Rouhani also honored Soleimani’s accomplishments, calling him a hero of Iranian history who defended against terrorism. “I condemn this cruel act but at the same time honor the brilliant service of this brave and enduring hero of Iranaposs history who defended the countryaposs territorial integrity and led the fight against terrorism and extremism in the region.” Soleimani was head of the Revolutionary Guardsapos Quds Force, an elite unit that handles Iranaposs overseas operations - and one deemed to be a foreign terrorist organization by the US.

title: bob braves the shave for charity
story: An Angus man has “braved the shave” in aid of cancer charities.Bob McGregor, , from Monieth, had his head shaved to raise money for prostate cancer research.The shave took place in The Vault in Monieth where Bob is a regular.The shave was carried out by another Vault regular Scott Reid.Bob had decided to undertake the fundraiser as several friends have suffered from the disease.He said: “I was happy to have my head shaved to raise funds for this very worthwhile charity.“I had a lot of support from family and friends as well as from all the regulars at The Vault.“It was a great day and I managed to raise more than £ for prostate cancer charities.“I’d like to thank Scott for being brave enough to shave my head and everyone who donated money to this very worthwhile cause.”Bob added that it was great that so many people turned up to watch.

title: dee utd team of the decade the best of 2010s
story: Greg Stewart or Johnny Russell  Gary Mackay-Steven or Gary Harkins  Darren O’Dea or Sean Dillon Who is the best we’ve seen in the City of Discovery over the past  years As we head into the s, Tele Sport writers George Cran and Calum Woodger looked back over the decade and, after a debate on the Twa Teams, One Street podcast, brought together the EveningTeam of the Decade.Goalkeeper: Scott BainArriving at Dens Park a year before the club won the Championship, Bain made himself club No  in the Premiership.After  appearances for the club, Bain left for Celtic and has played three times for Scotland.Defence: Gary IrvineA favourite among Dundee fans who crowned Irvine ‘the White Cafu’ after a flurry of goals from right-back, the defender made almost  appearances for the club.Defenders: Sean DillonA modern day club legend, ‘Dillo’ spent more than  years at Dundee United, winning the Scottish Cup in .He went on to captain the club for four seasons in the top-flight before departing in  after making  appearances in tangerine.James McPakeDillon and McPake shook hands six times as captains in Dundee derbies, with the United man getting the better of the results.McPake, though, is remembered as a player for two derby goals – one in a - win for his side and the second a late leveller at Tannadice.He may only have made  appearances for the club before injury ended his career early but McPake’s leadership on the pitch earns him a place in this team.Andrew RobertsonVery little has to be said about this choice – Robertson was a star in the making at Tannadice.Arriving as an unknown -year-old from Queen’s Park, Robertson swtly made the left-back place his own and became well-known for rampaging runs down the flank.Just a year later, he was off to Hull City for £. million and has since become a European Cup winner with Liverpool and Scotland captain.His  games for United brought five goals.Midfielders:Gary Mackay-StevenThe wing wizard edged out Dundee favourite Gary Harkins for the right-wing berth in our team.‘GMS’ was an entertainer with an array of tricks and flicks and was a major part of the free-flowing football that made the Tangerines a regular top-six outfit under Jackie McNamara.Stuart ArmstrongArmstrong and ‘GMS’ were inseparable at the top end of Scottish football for years before the former moved down south to Southampton.Armstrong’s athleticism and ability on the ball made him the focal point of United’s attack during six years at the club from  to .Kevin ThomsonHe may only have played  times for the Dens Park club.However, Thomson’s ability and nous in the middle of the park played a huge role in Dundee’s top-six finish in -.Craig ConwayA man scoring two goals in a Scottish Cup Final win is a must for a team like this.A compact, tricky attacker, Conway went on to enjoy a fine career for himself down south after making his name at Tannadice.Strikers: Greg StewartPlucked from Cowdenbeath, Stewart was arguably Dundee’s Player of the Decade.Shortlisted for the - PFA Scotland Players’ Player of the Year award, Stewart terrorised Premiership defences in dark blue.Twenty-two league goals in  top-flight matches from his time at the club is a sizeablewith his trademark curled finishes a regular sight at Dens Park.Jon DalyAnother Scottish Cup winner in his time in the city, Daly was a colossus for Dundee United.A real targetman, Daly was key in the early part of the decade with - a bumper year with  league goals in the top flight after winning the Scottish Cup in .The Irishman managed  goals in just over  games for the club –  of those goals came after .Manager: Peter HoustonShortly after taking over from Craig Levein, Houston led the Tangerines to a famous Scottish Cup triumph in  – only the second United manager to ever lt the trophy.Have your say on Tele Sport’s choices by emailing sport@eveningtelegraph
